Vita  pa&slong;&slong;io sce᷍ sancte
Cecilie virginis  martir᷒ martiris ·
Seinte Cecilie of noble kynde Ibore ibore ȝe was at rome Rome
Oure louerd cri&slong;t Crist ȝe louede wel ar ȝe fram cradel come
Stilleliche ȝe hire let baptiȝe as we fynden Iwryte iwryte
To oure louerd cri&slong;t Crist ȝe bad ȝerne hire maydenhod to wyte
So þat þoru &slong;trengþe of hire frendes Ispou&slong;ed ispoused ȝe was to a man
Of gret nobleye ȝ & of riche&slong;&slong;e his name was Vallerian
Þis mayde werede robe of pal ȝ & cloþes swiþe riche
Garlaundes ȝ & tre&slong;&slong;oures of gold þe here next hire liche
Whane ȝe herde men&slong;trales song · ȝe song in hire men&slong;tralcie
Þis mayde &slong;tiliche song of god God
ȝ & of his moder marye Marye
A vers of þe p&slong;alter hire song was weron was ma&slong;t hire þout
Lat louerd myn herte wiþoute wem be þͭ þat it co&combtilde;fu&combtilde;det confundet be naut
Anyȝt as ȝe was in riche bed wiþ hire lord ibrouth
Sone he hadde of folye þis clene mayde besout
Swete herte þis mayde seyde for loue þou ha&slong;t to me
Graunte me y mowe þe telle a litel pryuete
Þat ich me mowe þerof schryue ȝ & ·
þͭ þat þou it wille hele
Certe&slong; lemman þis ȝung man seyde noþi&combtilde;g noþing telle I nele
Suete lemman þis mayde seyde in warde icham Ido ido
An aungel of heuene is my wardeyn ȝ & my lemman þerto
Wel fa&slong;te he &slong;tant her bi me ȝif he vnderȝete
Þat þou benome my maydenhod noþing nolde he lete
74 231
Þat he ne wolde harde smyte ȝ & benyme þe þi myȝthe
Of þi ȝungne&slong;&slong;e ȝ & of noble &slong;tat for þou ne myȝth wiþ him fyȝtthe
Ac ȝif he wi&slong;te þou louede&slong;t me in gode loue ȝ & clene
Wytte he wolde þe als he deþ me ȝ & al yuel fro þe ȝeneHorstmann transcribes "wytte" but wonders whether the word should be read "wytie". At very high magnification, there is a trace of a diacritic above the letter that could be read "i". However, it might be a stray mark connected to the descender of "f" in "ȝif" in the preceding line. Since the letter also appears to have a cross-stroke, I have also transcribed the word as "wytte".
Ȝif þou wilt seyde Vallerian þat ich Ileue ileue þis
Þen angel þou mo&slong;t me schewe þat I se hym Iwis iwis
Ȝ & wanne I þat soþe ise þat þou ha&slong;t soþ iseyd
In clene&slong;&slong;e forsoþe þi wille I do al after þi red
Ȝif I se þat in folye þou loue&slong;t anoþer þan me
Noþing ne schal ȝou helpe þat I ne sle him ȝ & þe
Swete herte seyde þat mayde ȝ & þou wile þe aungel se
Þou mo&slong;t bileuen on ihu&combmacr; Ihesu
cri&slong;t Crist

Icri&slong;tned icristned be
Ȝ & sen him þou schalt ȝif þou wilt so he þe wile wytte fro helleThe letter after "wyt" has neither a cross-stroke nor a diacritic, so that it is impossible to tell whether the word should be read as "wytte" or "wytie". I follow line 26 in adopting the former.
So gret ioye of oure loue schal be þat no tunge ne may telle
Ac henne ouer þre myle þou mo&slong;t gon þe wey to apye Apye
Þere men þou schalt fynde on ihu&combmacr; Ihesu
cri&slong;t Crist fa&slong;te crye

þͭ þat he þe teche anon

vrban Urban þe holi old man for þou mo&slong;t to him gon
ffor priue coun&slong;eil þou wilt wiþ him speke. ȝ & he þe schal baptiȝe
Ȝ & þanne þou schalt þan angel se ȝ & do as he þe wile wi&slong;e
Vallerian aros anon as oure louerd him ȝaf wille
To þe &slong;tede þe mayde bad he wende forþ wel &slong;tille
Þes pore men him taute anon to þe olde seint Seint
vrban Urban
he fond him in an old forlate &slong;tede þat þer wonede neuere man·

Were cecilie Cecilie haue him now ymad him þͭ þat was so wilde

hor wiþ whyte ve&slong;temens a swiþe fair wryt he ber

To sein Seinte
Cecilie he wente aȝen þo he was þare i&slong; fulle
he fond hire chambre lyȝth wiþinne · ȝ & swiþe swote smulle
he fond cecilie Cecilie his gode spou&slong;e ȝ & an aungel wiþ hire stonde
Bryȝttere þan any leme twey garlondes he hadde on hondeHorstmann reads "lome" and corrects it to "leme", but the first vowel does not differ significantly from the second, so there is no reason to think that it was not correctly written.
Of ro&slong;e ȝ & of lilie swote þat on cecilie Cecilie he tok
Ȝ & þat oþer vallerian Vallerian as we fynden in bok
Wyteþ þis wiþ trewe loue wiþ cha&slong;te body ȝ & clene

fforfalewe ne olde · wille þei nat ac euere he willeþ la&slong;te

Þe ro&slong;e betokneþ ȝoure martirdom for þeron deye ȝe mote
And for þou de&slong;t vallerian Vallerian
cecilie Cecilie red so sone
What þou beseke&slong;t of my lord he wille þe graunte sone
I ne wille noþing so miche · seyde vallerian Vallerian
Bote þat Tiburft Tiburs my broþer wiþ me were cri&slong;teneman Cristene man

Ȝ & boþe ȝe schulle Imartired imartired be at o tyme in o place

wende wiþ þis word he nu&slong;te wher he becom

he stod ȝ & beheld alaboute als he nu&slong;te wher he were
Broþer he seyde hou goþ þis þis tyme of þe ȝere
So swote smul ne smelde I neuere me þinkþ as I do here
Þei þis hous were ful of newe ro&slong;es ȝ & of lylie al&slong;o

So ful ich am al of þe smul ȝ & so muche it is in my þout

Oþer I stonde in matyngge · ȝ & mete þat so it is·

vallerian Vallerian we habbeþ euere Ibe ibe

Today þou schalt my broþer be for þou wilt don be rede

Mid vallerͤan Vallerian þou mo&slong;t go to þe bi&slong;&slong;chop vrban Vrban The abbreviation mark in "Vallerian" loks like a hook open on the right, which is not listed in the MUFI character recommendation. It is sufficiently similar to the "e" in "cristned" on the following line, that I have decided to represent it as a superscript "e" in the encoding.

⧶ Seint/ Seinte
cecilie Cecilie com be þe pr&slong;on loude ȝe gan gredeThe scribe seems to have been reluctant to write an "e" at the end of "seinte", perhaps because it would have closely resembled the "c" in "cecilie". Instead, he wrote a wavy diagonal line that seems to serve as a divider between the two words.
What do ȝe godes knytes kuþeþ ȝour &slong;taleworthede
Fyȝteþ nou &slong;taleworþliche to leue þis derkhede
Þat ȝe were in þe weye ibrouth þͭ þat to cler lyȝt schal ȝou lede
Opon þe morue to þe maumets þis gode men were brouth

here heued he let of smyte ȝ &
maxime Maxime it Isey isey

Ich isey þe gode mannes soule aungles to heuene lede
Þe Iu&slong;ti&slong;e iustise him let nymen anon naked he let him bete
Wiþ &slong;tronge skourgen fa&slong;te ibounde forto he gan þat lif lete

Þese þre holy martires ȝe burede togydere anon·

artou Vallerianus wif be þe fey Ich owe mahoun·

it iseye loude ȝe wopen ȝ & gradde

Mi ȝongge lif ne lese I nowth ac to lyue Icham ibrouth
Ane schorte deþ I schal avonge ȝ & lif wiþouten ende
ffol he were þat nolde al&slong;o god God he me sone hyne sende

Mo þan four hondred become cri&slong;tene Cristene in þat place

halfslawe he leuede hire so aweyward he gan hye
Nou an yuel &slong;tede gon he mote for he was a schreweThe first five words of this line are written in a smaller hand with slighly lighter ink, as if the scribe had left space for them and added them slightly later.

ffor whoso nu&slong;te of no doel þer men myȝtte it se
⧶ Þis holi mayde ȝede aboute hire heued half ofsmyte
Ȝ & was half quik ȝ & half ded þat rewþe it was to wyte
Ȝ & pouere men mechel of hire good ȝe delde wiþ hire honde
It was a wel fair grace of god God þat ȝe aut myȝtte &slong;tonde
Ȝe prechede ȝ & to Ihu&combmacr; Ihesu
cry&slong;t Cry&slong;t many a god man wende
Ȝ & alle to seint Seint
vrban Urban þe bi&slong;&slong;chop to baptiȝe ȝe hem sende
Ȝ & bad þat he scholde hire hous þat ȝe hadde woned Inne inne
halewen in oure louerdes name ȝ & a churche þer bigynne·
And burien þere hire swete body ȝ & þat oure louerdes serui&slong;e
Vpe his poer þerinne were ido on allekynne wy&slong;e
Þe þridde day after hire martirdom þe mayde adoun lay
And prechede to þe cri&slong;tenemen Cristene men
ȝ & bad hem habbe god day
Ȝ & seyde now ich habbe ido al þat my wille is to
Wende I wile to ihu&combmacr; Ihesu
cri&slong;t Crist
ȝ & ȝe schulle al&slong;o
Þis was two hundred ȝer · ȝ & þre ȝ & twenti ryȝth
After þat oure louer louerd was in his moder alyȝth
Nou bidde we oure swete louerd for hire martirdom
To bringge vs to þat ioye þat hire soule to com· Amen·
